As you probably know the Department of Audio-Visual Instruction of
the National Education Association has been interested for many years
in the development of educational television. Through our publica¬
tion, Audio-Visual Communication Reviewf and the work of our commit¬
tees, we have endeavored to advance among our membership an under¬
standing of the potential of educational television and a genuine
competency to use it to the fullest possible advantage*
MARGARET W. DIVIZIA
Supervisor, Audio-Visual Section,
Los Angeles City Schools

We have been limited in this work by the lack of budget and staff
time. Here at the National Education Association, this is the
period of preparing the annual budget. We in this division are
putting in our budget a recommendation that a full-time professional
specialist in educational television be added to the staff (l) to
work with the other divisions and departments of the National Educa¬
tional Association in the better development and utilization of
educational television, (2) to work with the membership of our
organization, and (3) to provide leadership in the general area of
the classroom production, application, and utilization of educational
television.
PAUL W. F. win
Professor of Education, Teachers
College, Columbia University

In justifying this request for an added staff member, we would appre¬
ciate letters expressing your personal or organizational views. I
would like to use these letters with the administrative authorities
of the National Education Association as evidence of the views of
your organization. I am writing similar letters to the Joint Commit¬
tee on Educational Television, the Association for Education by
Radio-Television, the Educational Television and Radio Center, and
the U. S. Office of Education.
mary c. welch If you find it possible and convenient to accede to this request.
Administrative Assistant we would appreciate having the letters by April 12 in order that we
may present them with our budget estimate.
Yours sincerely,
Floyde E. Brooker
